senses.de: To form an opinion or conclusion about something or someone.
senses.ex: The teacher judged the students' essays.

Tips.title: Context Matters
Tips.description: The context can influence whether 'judge' implies quick, superficial assessment or a thoughtful conclusion.
Tips.example: I shouldn't judge her choice without knowing the reasons.

Tips.title: Avoid Snap Judgments
Tips.description: 'Judge' often carries a negative connotation when decisions are made too quickly.
Tips.example: Don't judge a book by its cover.

Tips.title: Neutrality Implied
Tips.description: Using 'judge' can imply an attempt at neutrality or absence of bias.
Tips.example: The committee judged all entries on merit alone.

senses.de: To decide a result in a competition or contest.
senses.ex: He was asked to judge the singing competition.

Tips.title: Expertise Required
Tips.description: To 'judge' a competition often requires subject matter expertise or an artistic sense.
Tips.example: As a renowned chef, he was invited to judge the cook-off.

Tips.title: Impartiality Expected
Tips.description: Judging a contest implies fairness and lack of bias towards the competitors.
Tips.example: She struggled to judge the contest impartially, as her brother was participating.

senses.de: A person who has the power to make decisions on matters brought before a court of law.
senses.ex: The judge will soon announce his verdict.

Tips.title: Authority Figure
Tips.description: As a noun, 'judge' refers to someone with official authority, especially in a legal context.
Tips.example: The judge dismissed the irrelevant testimony.

Tips.title: Symbol of Justice
Tips.description: A judge symbolizes law and order, and is expected to uphold fairness and justice.
Tips.example: The judge is the guardian of justice in the courtroom.

senses.de: To estimate or determine something, such as a number or value.
senses.ex: Can you judge the distance between these two points?

Tips.title: Assessment Skill
Tips.description: Judging a number or value requires skill or experience to estimate accurately.
Tips.example: He judged the weight of the fish at 15 pounds.

Tips.title: Guesswork Involved
Tips.description: Sometimes 'judge' indicates an educated guess rather than a precise calculation.
Tips.example: Can you judge how long we'll need to wait?

senses.de: To make a moral judgement or find fault in someone or their actions.
senses.ex: Who are you to judge my actions?

Tips.title: Moral Implication
Tips.description: 'Judge' can imply moral superiority, often viewed negatively in casual conversation.
Tips.example: He judged my decision, though he wasn't in my shoes.

Tips.title: Subjective Nature
Tips.description: When used personally, 'judge' suggests a subjective rather than an objective viewpoint.
Tips.example: People may judge her lifestyle choices, but she's happy.

Adjudicator.wordDefinition:
An adjudicator is a person who settles a dispute or decides on a particular matter, especially in a non-legal context. For example, a school might have an adjudicator to resolve conflicts between students or a competition might have an adjudicator to determine the winner.

An adjudicator is used in non-legal contexts to make decisions and settle disputes while a judge is used in legal contexts to preside over legal proceedings and make legal judgments.

Appraiser.wordDefinition:
An appraiser is someone who values items or property based on their market worth. They typically work in the field of real estate, art, jewelry, or antiques.

An appraiser tells you how much something is worth while a judge decides who is right or wrong in a legal matter. Appraisers work in the field of valuing items, while judges work in the field of law.

Arbiter.wordDefinition:
An arbiter typically refers to a person who is chosen to settle a dispute between two parties or a person who has the authority to make a final decision in a situation.

Generally, an arbiter is used more in situations where two parties are trying to reach a resolution but cannot agree, such as in marriage counseling or arbitration, while a judge is used in legal situations where a crime has been committed or a contract has been violated.

Assessor.wordDefinition:
An assessor is a person who evaluates or determines the value, quality or worth of something. For example, a real estate assessor evaluates the value of a property for tax purposes, or an insurance assessor appraises the value of a damaged car.

Assessors do not make decisions on legal issues or impose penalties.

In short, assessors evaluate the worth of something while judges make legal decisions and impose penalties in a court of law.

Critic.wordDefinition:
A critic is someone who gives their opinion on something, usually related to art, movies, music, books, etc. They evaluate and analyze the piece of work and express their thoughts on it, highlighting both its good and bad aspects.

For example, a movie critic might review a new film and share their thoughts on whether it was good or bad, whereas a judge presides over a court case and makes a decision on someone's guilt or innocence based on the evidence.

Critics are applicable in the world of art and entertainment, while judges are found in the legal system.

Examiner.wordDefinition:
An examiner is someone who evaluates or tests something or someone. They usually assess a person's knowledge or skills during an examination, such as a teacher or an examiner for a driving test.

An examiner makes a decision based on the performance of the person they are evaluating.

An examiner evaluates, while a judge presides and makes decisions in legal cases.

Inspector.wordDefinition:
An inspector is someone who checks things to make sure they are safe, functioning properly, and following rules and regulations.

For example, a building inspector checks to make sure a building is safe to live or work in, while a food inspector checks food to make sure it's safe to eat.

An inspector focuses on ensuring things are safe and following regulations, while a judge focuses on making legal decisions and upholding the law.

Referee.wordDefinition:
A referee is a person who oversees sports and games. They make sure that the rules of the game are followed and settle any disputes that might arise.

Referees are usually found on sports fields and in other competitive settings.

A judge oversees legal proceedings and makes legal decisions, while a referee oversees sports and games and ensures that the rules are followed.

quotes.Text: I like all types of women. I accept them as they are when they come into my life... But I'm not a romantic. I'm just up-front. I like to be a part of something real, not make-believe. I tell women to tell me the truth, to just lay it out. Let me be the judge and decide if I want you around or not. Let me have my choice.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Future

quotes.Text: Don't ever know who you may meet, or just because a person may not be dressed up all fancy, don't mean they're not an important person. You just don't ever know who you're gonna meet in life. So that's why I look at everybody as equal. Can't just judge. I treat everybody with respect. Every man.

quotes.Text: It's a complete lie, why do people buy these papers? It's not the truth I'm here to say. You know, don't judge a person, do not pass judgement, unless you have talked to them one on one. I don't care what the story is, do not judge them because it is a lie.

quotes.Text: When you are in the public eye, you have to protect yourself. There are so many people judging you. I just try to be myself.

quotes.Text: I look to a day when people will not be judged by the color of their skin, but by the content of their character.

quotes.Text: Children begin by loving their parents; after a time they judge them; rarely, if ever, do they forgive them.

quotes.Name: Oscar Wilde

quotes.Text: I find hope in the darkest of days, and focus in the brightest. I do not judge the universe.

quotes.Name: Dalai Lama

quotes.Text: One of the first things I was taught as an actor was, 'Don't judge the character.
